title: Jake's Battle with Tennis Elbow
clinical_history: Jake is a 42-year-old software engineer who spends most of his day at a desk. He started experiencing pain on the lateral aspect of his right elbow about three months ago. Jake began a new tennis regimen with increased frequency, playing 4-5 times a week. About a month after the increased activity, he noted a sharp pain in his right elbow after an intense game. The pain appeared with specific movements, such as lifting his coffee mug or typing for extended periods. Jake reports the pain as (P1) a sharp, burning sensation directly at the lateral elbow and (P2) a secondary aching that radiates into his forearm, particularly when gripping objects tightly.

nprs.affected_area: distal forearm radiating from the elbow

aggrevating_factors: gripping objects, typing for more than 30 minutes, and playing tennis, particularly with backhand strokes.
picture: [insert image of forearm with focus on lateral elbow region]
easing_factors: ice application to the area 2-3 times a day, rest from tennis activities, and use of a forearm brace
past_history: No previous elbow or arm injuries. He did, however, experience a rotator cuff injury on the same side two years ago, which was resolved with physical therapy.
medical_history: Jake is generally healthy with no significant medical issues. He is slightly overweight and has started a lifestyle modification to address this with increased physical activity.
personal_history: Jake lives a sedentary lifestyle at work but has been actively trying to become healthier. Married with two children, he dedicates weekends to coaching his children's youth soccer team. No family history of musculoskeletal disorders.
imaging: None to date, but clinical symptoms point towards lateral epicondylitis.
